title: Object pronouns

lessonContent.text: In Spanish, as in English, there are two types of object pronouns – direct and indirect. In a sentence such as:

label1: My brother sent a letter to his girlfriend.

lessonContent.text: 'My brother' is the subject of the verb, i.e. the person who carried out the action of the verb; 'a letter' is the direct object, i.e. the thing which directly received the effect of the verb; and 'his girlfriend' is the indirect object, i.e. she benefits from the act of sending and therefore plays an indirect role in the process.
In English the indirect object is often introduced by 'to' or 'for', but sometimes a change in word order leads to the 'to' or 'for' being omitted:

label1: My brother sent his girlfriend a letter.

subCh2: Direct objects and direct object pronouns

lessonContentSubCh2.text: When the direct object of a verb is a person, it must always be preceded by a in Spanish – this is called the personal a:

The direct object pronouns in Spanish correspond to the six persons of the verb and are as follows:

words2: them (masc. people or objects) or you (polite pl., masc.)
them (fem. people or objects) or you (polite pl., fem.)

lessonContentSubCh2.text: Direct object pronouns are generally placed before the verb, for example:

words1: We see him./We see it. (masc. sing.)/We see you. (polite sing. masc.)
They see her./We see it. (fem. sing.)/We see you. (polite sing. fem.)
We see them. (masc.)/We see you. (polite pl. masc.)
We see them. (fem.)/We see you. (polite pl. fem.)

lessonContentSubCh2.text: The third person pronouns lo and la are often replaced by le when the direct object is a person rather than a thing:
This is known as leísmo and is more common in Spain, particularly central Spain, than in Latin America.
We have seen that the direct object pronoun generally comes before the main verb, but there are some cases where the pronoun is added to the end of the verb form – notably the infinitive:

words1: I am going to buy it.
We are going to visit you tomorrow.

lessonContentSubCh2.text: *There is an alternative position for the pronoun in these sentences – i.e. Lo voy a comprar/Te vamos a visitar mañana – but at this stage it is better to add it to the infinitive.

subCh3: Indirect objects and indirect object pronouns

lessonContentSubCh3.text: In Spanish the indirect object is always preceded by the preposition a:

words1: Juan escribe una carta a su novia.
words2: John writes a letter to his girlfriend./ John writes his girlfriend a letter.

lessonContentSubCh3.text: Remember that in Spanish an a may also introduce the direct object of a verb when the direct object is a person (the personal a – see above). So in the case of a sentence such as

the a does not mean 'to' and is simply introducing the direct object, since María is the person directly affected by the verb – she is seen. Therefore a María would be replaced by a direct object pronoun and not an indirect one:
As we have just seen with direct objects, indirect object can be replaced by a pronoun. These pronouns are called indirect object pronouns:

words2: John gave the letter to her.

lessonContentSubCh3.text: Once again, in Spanish the six pronouns correspond to the six persons of the verb:

You will see that le can mean 'to him', 'to her', 'to it' and 'to you'. Similarly, les can mean 'to them', 'to you'. If there is any uncertainty about the meaning of the pronoun it is possible to use the forms: a él, a ella, a Vd., a ellos, a ellas and a Vds. after the verb for clarification, but these forms can never replace the indirect object pronouns, le and les:

As with the direct object pronoun, the indirect object pronoun comes in front of the verb. If the verb is in the infinitive, the best thing at this stage is to add the pronoun directly to the infinitive:

words1: Voy a darle el libro (a él).
words2: I am going to give him the book.

lessonContentSubCh3.text: If both a direct object pronoun and an indirect object pronoun occur in the same sentence, the indirect pronoun is placed before the direct pronoun:

words2: My parents give it to you.

lessonContentSubCh3.text: This also applies if the pronouns are added to the end of the infinitive:

words2: I am going to give it to you.

lessonContentSubCh3.text: *Note that a stress mark now becomes necessary – see introductory section on 'Pronunciation'

There is one further detail that you need to be aware of and this is what happens when there are two pronouns together, both beginning with l … (e.g. le for 'to him' and lo for 'it'). In such cases the first of the two pronouns is replaced by se, whether it is singular or plural:
If there is any possible ambiguity, a él, a ella, a usted, etc. can be added for clarity (see above).

bContent: Argentina es uno de los países más grandes del mundo y está situada en América del Sur. Tiene muchos contrastes geográficos y climáticos debido a su extensión: los glaciares y altas montañas (en la Tierra de Fuego y la Patagonia), las Pampas y la región de bosques de las cataratas de Iguazú. Buenos Aires es la capital. Es una ciudad con grandes influencias europeas, sobre todo en su arquitectura. Además de los españoles, Argentina también tiene una gran población de descendientes de inmigrantes italianos.

Culturalmente, Argentina es también un país muy rico: el tango es conocido en el mundo entero y nadie lo baila ni lo canta como los argentinos. En literatura encontramos autores tan importantes como Jorge Luis Borges o Julio Cortázar.
